oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/120394</identifier><datestamp>2011-01-26T14:50:43Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_687</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>‘Veniamo da Lontano e Andiamo Lontano’: the Italian Left and the problem of transition</dc:title><dc:creator>Edwards, Phil</dc:creator><dc:subject>Italian politics</dc:subject><dc:subject>Democratic Party</dc:subject><dc:subject>Transition</dc:subject><dc:subject>Democratic consolidation</dc:subject><dc:subject>Second Republic</dc:subject><dc:subject>Post-Communist parties</dc:subject><dc:description>A key challenge for the Italian Left is the problematic of ‘transition’: the
enduring perception that Italy has not yet attained a state of democratic normality. The Left
has suffered a series of setbacks and crises since the formation of the Democratic Party
(Partito Democratico, PD) in 2007, thanks in large part to the adoption by PD leader
Walter Veltroni of a novelty-oriented strategy which failed to address the ‘transition’
agenda. Veltroni’s successor, Pierluigi Bersani, has mobilised a formidable nationwide
coalition of support for a more conservative approach, cutting across the ideological
divisions which persist within the PD. However, Veltroni’s strategy has created enduring
problems for his party, including the effective delegitimation of the far Left; only when this
is remedied will a revival of the broader Left, and a successful engagement with the
problems of transition, become possible.</dc:description><dc:description>Full text of this article is available at http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_140175_en.pdf</dc:description><dc:publisher>University of Glasgow, Faculty of Law, Business and Social Sciences</dc:publisher><dc:date>2011-01-26T14:50:42Z</dc:date><dc:type>Article</dc:type><dc:identifier>Bulletin of Italian Politics, 2009, vol. 1, no. 2, pp. 211-32</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/120394</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://www.gla.ac.uk/departments/politics/bulletinofitalianpolitics/</dc:relation><dc:relation>http://www.gla.ac.uk/media/media_140175_en.pdf</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
